Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Integrative Training in Health-Assistive Smart Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) project at Washington State University supports the development of a multi-disciplinary doctoral training program focused on designing and studying health-assistive smart environments. This IGERT will provide integrated training in the complementary disciplines of computer science, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, psychology, sociology, and health care to prepare scientists who can design smart environment techniques and use them to study aging and the development of health interventions. The faculty of the program will develop collaborative and sustaining interdisciplinary research opportunities in this area, provide new interdisciplinary classes that combine theoretical and practical learning experiences, and build leadership and cooperation skills through team problem-solving. Students will obtain real-world experience through internships and will understand user needs by living in on-campus smart environments. This IGERT program will partner with on-campus Research Experiences for Undergraduates programs, enhancing participation by students from underrepresented groups. IGERT participants will conduct research to determine whether technology can automatically monitor and analyze human health and behavior, whether it can simulate human behavior and activities, whether it can enhance human physical and cognitive abilities, and whether these technologies can be accepted by society. This program is intended to make a contribution to a generation of a workforce that is trained in multiple, complementary disciplines and that will open the door to new avenues of health and science research. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision for our IGERT program is to change the culture of doctoral education from the traditional isolation of topics in science and engineering to an approach that integrates the study of psychology, sociology, health care, and engineering support for individuals with special needs. Our IGERT program was the first to provide transdisciplinary training in the research areas necessary to achieve health-assistive smart environments.

The research goal for our IGERT is to advance the state of the art in smart environments and study their role as a type of “Cognitive Prosthesis”, in which the smart environment operates alongside the human in order to monitor, maintain, and enhance their capabilities and overcome their limitations. Outcomes of this research will be used to increase our understanding of the human being as a system and improve our smart environment designs. The impact of this research on society is that we will better understand human health and cognition and keep individuals with special needs functioning independently in their own homes. The hypothesis of our IGERT is that we can train PhDs to perform transdisciplinary research that advances the capabilities and design of smart environments to study and improve human health, cognition, and behavior. To investigate the design, usability, and testing issues for health-assistive smart environments, our IGERT Fellows were trained through multi-disciplinary, research-oriented classes in Gerontechnology, through internships, and through interactions with experts around the world.

In support of our research goal, we developed a smart home kit that can be used "out of the box" to collect, store, analyze, and utilize sensor data without disrupting the routines of smart home residents. We have deployed this kit into 70 homes around the world, many of which house older adult residents.  We have designed machine learning algorithms to discover, recognize, and predict activities that occur in these environments. Building on these algorithms students have designed approach to automated health assessment and intervention. Many of these research projects were in partnership with industry experts and clinicians.

This IGERT program funded 26 PhD students from the disciplines of Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Chemical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Physics, as well as Experimental Psychology, Clinical Psychology, Nursing, and Sociology. Over half of the students are women or from underrepresented groups. Twelve of these students have completed their PhD and are currently leaders in the field. Another seven will be completing their degrees this year. These students have received external validation for their work in terms of funded grants, published papers, best paper awards, NSF fellowships, and NSF research awards.


Last Modified: 09/02/2015
Modified by: Diane J Cook
